metadata.synopsis: Gale's default dialog that triggers whenever you speak to Gale in the game world. Covers a variety of topics that mostly react to Gale-related events that took place.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: Give him the Idol of Silvanus.

115.speaker: Gale
115.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

89.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Idol of Silvanus.

111.speaker: Gale
111.text: I can feel the storm abating. Yes, this will keep my condition in check - for a precious while.

56.speaker: Player
56.text: How long will that precious while last?

218.speaker: Gale
218.text: It's hard to predict the effect any given artefact has, but my condition is hardly a patient one.

79.speaker: Gale
79.text: Rather soon I will feel it stir again - like a distant thunder sending tremors through the soul.

195.speaker: Gale
195.text: I will need to consume another artefact before the lightning strikes. There's no choice but to find more.

100.speaker: Gale
100.text: In the meantime, my thanks again.

7.speaker: Gale
7.text: My liege, I bow to your boundless kindness!
7.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale theatrically bows.NodeContext: Tongue-in-cheek, but the sentiment is sincere.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: That condition of yours is a very expensive one.

213.speaker: Gale
213.text: I obtained it in Waterdeep. Nothing there comes cheap.
213.context: NodeContext: Tongue-in-cheek. He's in good spirits.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Thanks don't get me that artefact back.

207.speaker: Gale
207.text: I myself am a much more powerful artefact in your arsenal. Rest assured of that.

77.speaker: Player
77.text: I think I should be reimbursed for my efforts.

182.speaker: Gale
182.text: As long as we travel together, what's mine is yours. And if we survive our many ordeals, I'll host you a banquet in Waterdeep the likes of which you've never seen.

170.speaker: Gale
170.text: Such promises will have to wait however. My condition is hardly a patient one.

204.speaker: Player
204.text: So this is what regret feels like.

253.speaker: Gale
253.text: A feeling you may have to grow accustomed to while I'm around. My condition is hardly a patient one.

35.speaker: Gale
35.text: Gods, it's like a draught of cool water soothing a parched throat - welcome and wonderful.

27.speaker: Gale
27.text: There was a lot of magic in this artefact. I can't quite remember a time I've felt so peaceful inside.

91.speaker: Gale
91.text: It's good to perceive this constant fear repressed into a quiet scare. Let's hope it will last a good long while.
91.context: NodeContext: Relief, turning into good humour.

143.speaker: Gale
143.text: And I'm impressed once more by your benevolence!

217.speaker: Gale
217.text: I say that with great sincerity. Mere days have passed since our first acquaintance, but you've gained the respect of years.

227.speaker: Gale
227.text: As such, I do not wish to give you false hope. We're only treating the symptoms, not the cause.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: A constant fear? That sounds unpleasant.

159.speaker: Gale
159.text: Unpleasant, certainly. Gut wrenching too. Heart rending even, if pinched for an adjective.
159.context: NodeContext: Not actually very serious. He's in good spirits.

2.speaker: Gale
2.text: Then again - keeps you on your toes.

184.speaker: Gale
184.text: On a more serious note, I do not wish to give you false hope. We're only treating the symptoms, not the cause.

161.speaker: Gale
161.text: That said, this newfound calm I'm experiencing gives me reason to accept without prejudice a certain degree of optimism.

73.speaker: Gale
73.text: Time is a precious gift. With time, we may even reach Baldur's Gate, a city rife with magic, wizards, scholars, and perhaps: solutions.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: In that case I share your optimism. Here's to the journey ahead.

160.speaker: Gale
160.text: Oh, I can picture it now: academies, libraries, laboratories - the assembled knowledge of centuries that may just set us free.

98.speaker: Gale
98.text: Better yet: soft beds, home cooked meals, and all the other little luxuries this wilderness so brashly denies us.

191.speaker: Gale
191.text: Gods, I'd pay a king's ransom for a hot, lavender-scented bath - minstrels serenading as I close my eyes and let the water's warmth dissolve all woes.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: The tadpole is my main concern. I'm in need of solutions too.

238.speaker: Player
238.text: Baldur's Gate lies many miles to the west. Don't get your hopes up.

233.speaker: Player
233.text: Let's hope this was the last artefact I had to part with.

232.speaker: Gale
232.text: Come, come, these are mere fabled objects of great to enormous value.
232.context: NodeContext: Tongue-in-cheek. He's in good spirits.

186.speaker: Gale
186.text: My continued presence though - quite priceless!
186.context: NodeContext: Tongue-in-cheek. He's in good spirits.

93.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Iron Flask.

222.speaker: Player
222.text: Give him the Staff of Crones.

121.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Staff of Crones.

177.speaker: Player
177.text: Give him the Sword of Justice.

226.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Sword of Justice.

76.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of The Necromancy of Thay.

130.speaker: Gale
130.text: We'll need to find a way to unlock the book first.

109.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Night Walkers.

24.speaker: Player
24.text: Give him the Shadow of Menzoberranzan.

122.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Shadow of Menzoberranzan.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: Give him the Amulet of Selûne's Chosen.

3.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the Amulet of Selûne's Chosen.

146.speaker: Player
146.text: I'm not ready to part with an artefact yet.

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: I urge you to reconsider. There could be consequences beyond our ken.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: What will happen to this item should I give it to you?

193.speaker: Gale
193.text: I will consume the magic inside. What was a powerful artefact will be rendered no more than a trinket.

5.speaker: Gale
5.text: But it will save my life - even if only temporarily.

138.speaker: Gale
138.text: Sorry, if I'm to engage in banter, I prefer it to be with the leader of our troupe.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: Tell me a bit more about yourself.

246.speaker: Gale
246.text: Let's see. I hail from Waterdeep, the City of Splendours. I'm a wizard of considerable acclaim, and scholar of exceptional accomplishment.

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: I have a cat, a library, and a weakness for a good glass of wine. And if the mood takes me, I'm known to try my hand at poetry.

65.speaker: Gale
65.text: Didn't that paint enough of a picture?

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Try peering into his mind. If he won't open up, you'll sneak in.

252.speaker: Narrator
252.text: *For a split second you see a swirl of untamed magic - then his defences drop like a portcullis.*

46.speaker: Player
46.text: You're right - I'm sorry. Curiosity got the better of me.

63.speaker: Gale
63.text: Not an eventuality I'm entirely unfamiliar with.

71.speaker: Gale
71.text: Nevertheless, please don't try that again unless I invite you to.

131.speaker: Player
131.text: I saw something in your mind. A strange magic. What was it?

112.speaker: Gale
112.text: Nothing. What you saw was merely mental disorientation brought about by your intrusion.

172.speaker: Gale
172.text: Please don't try that again unless I invite you to.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: It's obvious you're withholding something. Explain.

86.speaker: Gale
86.text: And please don't try that again unless I invite you to.

59.speaker: Narrator
59.text: *Try as you might to breach his inner thoughts, Gale swats your efforts away with infuriating ease.*

67.speaker: Gale
67.text: I have a very disciplined mind: those tricks won't work on me.

135.speaker: Player
135.text: You're trying to brush me off. Don't you have anything other than generalities to offer?

249.speaker: Gale
249.text: Certainly. That I have a great respect for privacy, for instance - especially my own.

201.speaker: Player
201.text: I think I have a magical artefact you'll be interested in.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: That is most gratifying to hear. May I?

44.speaker: Player
44.text: That protocol of yours, why make it so difficult?

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: The instructions were easy enough, weren't they? If slightly elaborate.

190.speaker: Gale
190.text: Like I said: I'm dangerous even in death. I'm merely trying to protect those around me.

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: I find that a healthy amount of theatrics - a voice from the beyond, a magic flute, a friendly if highly combustible magma mephit - tends to make for a more compelling case.

216.speaker: Gale
216.text: If nothing else, I'm sure I piqued your curiosity.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: I was wondering, that condition of yours, why does it require magic?

6.speaker: Gale
6.text: Think of it as vampirism. You need blood to sustain yourself, I need magic.

166.speaker: Gale
166.text: It has become my sustenance. Without it... Well, I hardly need to tell you.

229.speaker: Gale
229.text: Think of it as... tribute. The kind a king might pay to a more powerful neighbour to avoid invasion.

142.speaker: Gale
142.text: As long as I pay there will peace. But should I ever stop, along comes a war.

181.speaker: Gale
181.text: I can assure the battlefield would extend well beyond the borders of my body alone.

53.speaker: Gale
53.text: 'An eruption the size of Waterdeep', I think my exact words were.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: I never realised it was so easy to cast magic.

127.speaker: Gale
127.text: I assure you it is not.

57.speaker: Gale
57.text: Don't get me wrong, you did well! The somatic component, the vocal component, even the focus on the inner self that invites Mystra in.

179.speaker: Gale
179.text: But I was still your conduit. To perform such a feat alone requires much and arduous study.

74.speaker: Gale
74.text: Yet it is life's most worthy pursuit in my impartial if not humble opinion.

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: Of course, as a sorcerer, these talents come to you quite naturally. I do hope you cherish that gift.

198.speaker: Gale
198.text: Of course, as a warlock, your patron endows you with many such powers otherwise unattainable. I do hope you cherish that gift.

8.speaker: Gale
8.text: Of course, as a paladin, your patron deity endows you with many such powers otherwise unattainable. I do hope you cherish that gift.

243.speaker: Gale
243.text: Of course, as a cleric, your patron deity endows you with many such powers otherwise unattainable. I do hope you cherish that gift.

247.speaker: Player
247.text: Do you have much experience being a teacher of magic? I suspect so.

210.speaker: Gale
210.text: I've had a pupil or two, but never for very long. Their ineptitudes tend to... irk me.

236.speaker: Gale
236.text: You do seem to be a precocious talent though. I can always tell when I meet with a keen mind receptive to Mystra.

215.speaker: Gale
215.text: Keep it up and she might just take a personal interest in you one of these days.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: So what did you think about what I pictured when we were connected by the Weave?

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: Oh, I was surprised. But pleasantly so, just like I said.

234.speaker: Gale
234.text: Amid the madness that has befallen us, it seems almost out of place to think of a kiss.

78.speaker: Gale
78.text: Amid the madness that has befallen us, it seems almost out of place to think of a romantic walk.

206.speaker: Gale
206.text: And yet, now more than ever, it's important to recall what makes us human.

28.speaker: Gale
28.text: And yet, now more than ever, it's important to recall what makes us human. Well - you know what I mean.

133.speaker: Gale
133.text: A stolen glance - that sudden heartbeat... Sometimes the little things are worth more than kingdoms.

14.speaker: Gale
14.text: What did I think about an imaginary blow to the stomach?

141.speaker: Gale
141.text: Treating you to the real deal, that's what.

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: What did I think about seeing my head on a spike?

42.speaker: Gale
42.text: That I still looked as handsome as ever, that's what.

149.speaker: Gale
149.text: Why would you even bring this up? Come, let's go. I'm not in the mood for chatter.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: There's something I don't understand. If Mystra abandoned you, how can you still cast magic?

32.speaker: Gale
32.text: The Weave is still here, all around us - inside of us too. As long as the goddess lives, magic is a tangible thing for those who know how to touch.

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: I've studied magic for many years, and in as many ways I am still a more than capable wizard.

250.speaker: Gale
250.text: It's just that I'm no longer able to perform those feats even arch wizards would marvel at.

194.speaker: Gale
194.text: To have one hand on the pulse of divinity.

87.speaker: Gale
87.text: You have to remember that the Weave is a living thing, both the embodiment and the extension of Mystra herself.

102.speaker: Gale
102.text: She can give and she can take away. I'm afraid I'm still very much on her naughty list.

137.speaker: Player
137.text: You said you think about the moment we shared under the Weave. Do you think about it often?

116.speaker: Gale
116.text: You see, I'm not a big believer in fate, but I do believe in serendipity.

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: Life is a tempest of events that sometimes we brace against and sometimes embrace.

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: You're one such event that, one day soon perhaps, I'd like to embrace.

203.speaker: Gale
203.text: I do, as a matter of fact.

173.speaker: Player
173.text: When I said we could be more than friends, you answered 'perhaps'. What does that really mean?

30.speaker: Gale
30.text: If I recall correctly, the Waterdhavian Dictionary of the Common Tongue of Faerûn defines it as an adverb that conveys the meaning of 'it may be that', or 'possibly'.

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: Sorry, sometimes I just can't help being quite insufferable. In seriousness, I'm glad you asked that question.

178.speaker: Player
178.text: I was wondering about that 'mighty lord' you told me about in your story.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: I was wondering about that 'mighty lord' you told me about in your story. Karsus, I assume.

19.speaker: Gale
19.text: Karsus was perhaps the most powerful wizard that ever lived. The-child-who-would-be-a-god, the elves called him.

39.speaker: Gale
39.text: And he tried. With a spell of his own devising he endeavoured to usurp in one fell swoop the power of the goddess of magic.

118.speaker: Gale
118.text: Mystryl, she was called then. Imagine what it must have felt like. To be a god. To know yourself to be untouchable. To be mistaken.

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: As Karsus aimed his spell at her, she began to unravel, and with her, the entire Weave.

54.speaker: Gale
54.text: Too late did he realise what he had unleashed. It would have been the end of everything had not Mystryl sacrificed herself.

180.speaker: Gale
180.text: The goddess of magic is all magic. By dying, the entire Weave was lost, and the spell that challenged a god failed.

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: It was the end of Mystryl, the end of Karsus, and the end of an entire civilisation.

237.speaker: Gale
237.text: As the-child-who-would-be-a-god was turned to stone, his empire came crashing down around him. The floating cities of Netheril were no more.

48.speaker: Gale
48.text: An event that came to be known as Karsus' Folly.

196.speaker: Player
196.text: So at that moment in time, all magic was gone?

61.speaker: Gale
61.text: Mystryl was reborn as Mystra. Upon her return, the Weave returned with her.

70.speaker: Gale
70.text: Now, so many centuries later, I tried to follow in the footsteps of Karsus, not to destroy Mystra, but to prove my love for her.

202.speaker: Gale
202.text: I tried to control only a fraction of the magic that was unleashed that fateful day. I merely sought to return one tiny diamond to an imperfect crown.

66.speaker: Gale
66.text: Gale's Folly one might call it. History. Repetition. It's the way things go.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Praise be that Mystryl was reborn as Mystra.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: Nothing good ever comes from mortals wanting to be gods.

51.speaker: Gale
51.text: Loving them has its side effects as well.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: You have to admire the man's ambition. He very nearly succeeded.

139.speaker: Gale
139.text: If it takes the death of a god to stop you, I'd say your ambition has gotten somewhat out of hand.

82.speaker: Gale
82.text: Not that I'm one to talk, of course.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: If you ever feel the Netherese magic overtaking you, what will you do?

219.speaker: Gale
219.text: If it should ever come to that, if I ever know I am no longer able to stop it, I will do anything I can to ensure no one but me pays for my mistakes.

168.speaker: Gale
168.text: I will find the remotest place on the surface of Faerûn, or perhaps far below in the depths of the Underdark.

58.speaker: Gale
58.text: I will await that death alone.

23.speaker: Gale
23.text: I promise I will not betray your trust. You kept me by your side despite the menace that I am.

152.speaker: Gale
152.text: If worst comes to worst, I will be gone long before the curtain falls.

107.speaker: Gale
107.text: Before we go on though, do first let me apologise.

163.speaker: Gale
163.text: To share such a night with you only to tell you of a previous lover the next morning... It wasn't the most gentleman-like behaviour.

106.speaker: Gale
106.text: But I had to finally tell you. Silence would have been far worse behaviour still. Nevertheless, I am sorry.

189.speaker: Player
189.text: It's fine. In the end I'm glad you told me.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: I'm a bit disappointed you're not all gentleman.

254.speaker: Gale
254.text: One shouldn't be all gentleman. Or we certainly wouldn't have done some of things we did the other night.

187.speaker: Player
187.text: It was a rotten thing to do.

101.speaker: Gale
101.text: But you first approached me 'about the other night'. What was it you wanted to tell me?

167.speaker: Player
167.text: We should do it again sometime.

241.speaker: Gale
241.text: We absolutely should. After all, I need to undo the misconception you've had better.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: Perhaps it was all a mistake.

235.speaker: Gale
235.text: Then let me clear your mind of doubts: it absolutely wasn't.

9.speaker: Gale
9.text: It's cruel to tease, you know.

251.speaker: Gale
251.text: That's certainly a word for it.

4.speaker: Gale
4.text: I've had a goddess, but you don't hear me complaining.

153.speaker: Player
153.text: I need you to remain in the camp for a while, rather than on the road with me.

208.speaker: Gale
208.text: I question the wisdom of that decision, but so be it.

211.speaker: Player
211.text: Actually, never mind. We should stay together.

92.speaker: Player
92.text: Perhaps we'll travel together again later.

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: I'll be here in the meantime, idling away the hours.

221.speaker: Gale
221.text: I'll be in the camp then, idling away the hours.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: Join me, why don't you? There's plenty of adventure to be had.

225.speaker: Gale
225.text: There's room for adventure, but no room for me it seems. You have your fair share of followers already.
